_source.text:
The dialogue among Romeo and his friends twists and turns and presents some
difficulty in being understood.  Don’t be frustrated with their language;
their parents probably would have been, too, and we shouldn’t expect to
understand everything they say.  The scene is of chief importance for
introducing Mercutio, a pivotal character in the play’s plot and supposedly
one of Romeo’s close friends.  Read his speech, especially the famous
discussion of Queen Mab, carefully, noting the type of language he employs.
How does his language strike you when compared to Romeo’s?  Benvolio’s?
_source.quote: Enter ROMEO, MERCUTIO, BENVOLIO, with five or six Maskers, Torch-bearers, and others

_source.text:
Imagery of day.  “We burn daylight”—Mercutio intends a  figurative meaning,
that, as he says, they’re wasting time (“we waste our lights in vain”).  But
Romeo, in his moodiness, chooses to take him literally—“no,” he says, “we’re
not actually burning daylight.”  Romeo’s remark may seem the willful
misunderstanding of a moody teenager, but he inadvertently causes us to
consider a more profound meaning, one that is linked to the day/night imagery
running throughout the play: with their torches, these men are creating an
artificial daylight (so they can walk in the dark).  The torch is a means of
creating artificial day, just as by closing his shutters Romeo generated an
artificial night.  Shakespeare is playing with the notion of what constitutes
day, what constitutes night.  We’ve already seen that day has been associated
with light and sight and beauty and companionship; but here, at night, the
torches create an artificial light and facilitate the companionship of Romeo
and his friends.
_source.quote: Come, we burn daylight, ho!   /  ROMEO Nay, that's not so.   /  MERCUTIO I mean, sir, in delay   /  We waste our lights in vain, like lamps by day.

_source.text:
Another example of "humor theory." Personality was thought by many medical
authorities to be linked to liquid imbalances. Thicker blood meant a braver
personality, a sense the expression has retained in modern times.
_source.quote: make thick my blood;

_source.text:
Physiognomy, the ability to judge character from looking at people's faces, is
clearly an issue in this play (Duncan mentions this in I.4 when bemoaning his
inability to detect the treason of the rebellious Thane of Cawdor). But Lady
Macbeth's reference is more complex because the audience has already learned
that she doesn't trust Macbeth's ability to dissemble. "Your face" here could
mean "anyone's face" (what Duncan meant) or Macbeth's specifically (because
his human kindness makes him transparent).
_source.quote: Your face, my thane, is as a book where men   /  May read strange matters.

_source.text: "Leave the arrangements of tonight's great business to me"
_source.quote: put   /  This night's great business into my dispatch;

_source.text:
Mercutio’s last sally of obscenities: “medlar” is a euphemism for
“prostitute”; and the “open et cetera” and “pop’rin pear” represent the female
and male genitalia, respectively.
_source.quote: Now will he sit under a medlar tree,   /  And wish his mistress were that kind of fruit   /  As maids call medlars, when they laugh alone.   /  Romeo, that she were, O, that she were   /  An open et caetera, thou a poperin pear!

_source.text:
The following scene is, of course, one of the most famous passages in Western
literature.  As you read it for the first time, don’t try too hard to keep
track of all the imagery or to delineate the complexities of language; rather,
allow yourself to be transported by the lyrical beauty of the language, the
excitement of these two young lovers drinking the words of each other’s
utterance.  I’ll provide some signposts that flag thematic elements, but I’d
recommend reading the scene first and only then returning, on a second
reading, to my annotations.
_source.quote: But, soft! what light through yonder window breaks?   /  It is the east, and Juliet is the sun.

_source.text: Juliet again bids Romeo good night, threatening, once again, another parting.
_source.quote: A thousand times good night!

_source.text:
The Friar presents an oxymoron: the earth is at once a tomb and a womb—the
place where dead bodies lie and new bodies are born.  The metaphor, continuing
the language of oxymoron we’ve seen throughout the play, implies that death
and life are closely related.  Remember the “fatal loins” of the first act’s
prologue?

  
    The Friar introduces his metaphor as he begins to discuss herbs (the
children of the earth)—they can be used for good or ill, he says; an herb
that, when smelled, is beneficial, can, when eaten, kill.  “Virtue itself
turns vice, being misapplied” the Friar says (a few lines below this
citation).  As so often in his plays, Shakespeare presents philosophical
arguments in separate pieces—it is up to us, the audience/readers, to draw
together various ideas spoken by different characters.  Juliet has said that
“a rose by any other word would smell as sweet”—presenting the notion that
language (the names by which we call things) does not alter the identity of
things.  Now, the Friar argues that nature is not intrinsic—that is, that a
thing can be either good or evil—depending on how it is used.  Juliet and the
Friar take opposite stances: for Juliet, something is either good or bad,
regardless of how it is named; for the Friar, how we name something—i.e., how
our usage determines its name (poison if used to kill, medicine if used to
cure)—determines its nature.
_source.quote: The earth that's nature's mother is her tomb;   /  What is her burying grave that is her womb,

_source.text:
Note the Friar’s tendency to moralize—that is, to make pithy but somewhat
condescending statements encapsulating what he perceives to be a moral truth.
_source.quote: Be plain, good son, and homely in thy drift;   /  Riddling confession finds but riddling shrift.

_source.text:
The Friar’s remark shows us that he is a shrewd observer of character: he
realizes that Romeo’s “love” for Rosaline was actually manufactured rather
than real—that Romeo recycled the love-speech of older men (“did read by rote”
= memorized) without having himself created that language (“that could not
spell”).  The Friar is drawing our attention to Romeo’s initial lack of
individuality—his use of an already-existing language in lieu of speaking a
truly individual, new, unique language.
_source.quote: O, she knew well   /  Thy love did read by rote and could not spell.

_source.text: Recall the play’s categories of what is “feminine,” what “masculine.”
_source.quote: I'll play the housewife for this once.

_source.text:
We can believe more in the Nurse’s grief—for despite her betrayal of
Juliet (by suggesting that she commit bigamy and betray Romeo by marrying
Paris), she genuinely believed herself to be acting in Juliet’s best
interests.

  
    Note, too, her manner of mourning: she curses the _day_—both in the sense
of the specific date, and in the sense of _day_ as daytime (as opposed to
nighttime).  And, we recall, the precise time is _dawn_—sunrise.  With the
rise of the sun, the dawn of the new day, is discovered Death.  Just as the
imagery associated with day and night has been altered and sometimes inverted
throughout the play, here, the Nurse says “Never was seen so black a day as
this.”  Romeo created artificial night at the play’s opening; now does
Juliet’s “death” cast the day into the seeming darkness of grief.
_source.quote: O woe! O woful, woful, woful day!   /  Most lamentable day, most woful day,   /  That ever, ever, I did yet behold!   /  O day! O day! O day! O hateful day!   /  Never was seen so black a day as this:   /  O woful day, O woful day!

_source.text: Recall Capulet’s lines about Death lying with Juliet.
_source.quote: Well, Juliet, I will lie with thee to-night.   /  Let's see for means:

_source.text: Recall night’s capacity to mask, or hide.
_source.quote: muffle me, night, awhile.

_source.text:
And so the Friar repeats the tale.  Why?  What does such a long exposition
accomplish?  Might Shakespeare believe the audience missed any of the action?
Or what might be a more subtle, thematic reason for the Friar’s explanation?
Is Shakespeare giving the Friar a chance to confess?
_source.quote: I will be brief, for my short date of breath   /  Is not so long as is a tedious tale.

_source.text: Literally "for breeding."
_source.quote: procreant

_source.text:
Convoluted grammar characteristic of courtly praise and hyperbole: "We
continue praying for you [hermits were known to pray for a benefactor's soul],
thanking you for the old dignities [Glamis] and the new ones recently added to
them [Cawdor]."
_source.quote: for those of old,   /  And the late dignities heap'd up to them,   /  We rest your hermits.

_source.text:
Another grammatically twisted expression of feudal obligation. According to
feudal notions of property, the only "owner" of everything in society was the
monarch, who then allowed everyone else the use of what they had according to
their rank. Each member of society, except for the monarch, was then a
"servant" of whomever was higher in the social pyramid. Thanes like Macbeth
(and by bond of marriage, his wife) were immediately below the king in the
pyramid and lorded over everyone but him. Lady Macbeth means "we as your
servants have servants ("theirs"), their own persons, and their property
("what is theirs") as credit or trust ("in count"), and we are required to
settle their accounts ("make their audit") at your pleasure, and to return
what already belongs to you when we are asked to."
_source.quote: Your servants ever   /  Have theirs, themselves and what is theirs, in compt,   /  To make their audit at your highness' pleasure,   /  Still to return your own.

_source.text: An Early Modern wind instrument, from which the modern oboe evolved.
_source.quote: Hautboys

_source.text:
Macbeth's twisted reasoning continues (notice all the "buts") and this is
another passage open to varied interpretation. "In these cases" could refer to
regicide, a very specific crime at the top of the feudal pyramid of criminal
offenses. After pointing out the eternal damnation that he would be risking,
now Macbeth is also considering the consequences (the "judgement") that would
also occur on earth ("here") if he kills Duncan: the actions of a king (or
anyone with lordship over others) in the feudal system, are not mere actions
but also lessons, examples ("instructions") for those lower than them in the
pyramid. If the lessons are "bloody" (and regicide was the ultimate example of
this), once taught, they can always come back to haunt the teacher
("inventor"). The justice of the world (in addition to eternal, divine
justice) is blind ("even-handed") and if we put poison in a cup, it would
invariably send the cup back for us to drink from it. (Notice, Shakespeare
winking at his own plot device to resolve the conflcits in _Hamlet_ and
provide a rightful punishment for Claudius!)
_source.quote: But in these cases   /  We still have judgment here; that we but teach   /  Bloody instructions, which, being taught, return   /  To plague the inventor: this even-handed justice   /  Commends the ingredients of our poison'd chalice   /  To our own lips.

_source.text: Edge=erection here, with "take off my edge" meaning "lose your virginity."
_source.quote: It would cost you a groaning to take off my edge.

_source.text:
Fireworks.  "Don't be such a scaredy-cat.  It's just a _play_.  It's not real
life."
_source.quote: false fire!

_source.text:
"Back to reality!  I want to be out of the darkened, mirror-world of the
theater and back in my lighted, normal life."
_source.quote: Lights, lights, lights!

_source.text:
Oxford makes the somewhat dubious observation that Hamlet, having asked
Guildenstern to play upon the pipe, now "plays" upon the "windbag" Polonius.
I believe it's a hard case to make that Shakespeare intended to make that
particular pun, but the image of Polonius whistling and tooting like a
recorder as Hamlet throws him for loop after loop is a pretty funny one.
_source.quote: My lord, the queen would speak with you, and   /  presently.   /  HAMLET Do you see yonder cloud that's almost in shape of a camel?   /  LORD POLONIUS By the mass, and 'tis like a camel, indeed.   /  HAMLET Methinks it is like a weasel.   /  LORD POLONIUS It is backed like a weasel.

_source.text: Warmer climates were thought to harbor more contagious diseases.
_source.quote: contagion of the south

_source.text:
Keep your eye on how often cannibalism is invoked in this play--what do you
think this is about?
_source.quote: To the pot,

_source.text: plague
_source.quote: murrain

_source.text:
If any Shakespeare play were to be described as homoerotic, this would be the
one.  A more interesting explanation of these lines is that domestic pleasure
is worth less to Marcius than honor in battle and the companionship of his
fellow soldiers.  Remember, he is Volumnia's son: replace her discussion of
child-rearing in relation to warfare with his views on the marital bed, and
you see how closely the two mirror one another in their disdain for
domesticity.
_source.quote: let me clip ye  /  In arms as sound as when I woo'd, in heart  /  As merry as when our nuptial day was done,  /  And tapers burn'd to bedward!  /

_source.text:
The philosophies of battle held by Marcius and Cominius are extremely
different.  Marcius's is black and white; Cominius allows for more variability
(the Roman army had to retreat in order to win their purpose, something that
Marcius finds difficult to understand).
_source.quote: If not, why cease you till you are so?  /  COMINIUS   /  Marcius,  /  We have at disadvantage fought and did  /  Retire to win our purpose.  /

_source.text: we put ourselves to the proof (ie, attack).
_source.quote: prove

_source.text:
In _Henry V_, Shakespeare wrote [such an inspirational piece of military
rhetoric](http://www.chronique.com/Library/Knights/crispen.htm) that a
recording of [Sir Lawrence Olivier reciting
it](http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3jXFnQUU7yg&feature=related) was played on
the BBC nearly every evening in 1941.  Marcius's speech seems to have a
similar inspirational effect, yet the speech itself cannot compare to Henry's
nationalist enthusiasm.  Marcius, of course, is a man of action rather than
words: why, then, do his bland words have such an inspirational effect?
_source.quote: If any such be here--  /  As it were sin to doubt--that love this painting  /  Wherein you see me smear'd; if any fear  /  Lesser his person than an ill report;  /  If any think brave death outweighs bad life  /  And that his country's dearer than himself;  /  Let him alone, or so many so minded,  /  Wave thus, to express his disposition,  /  And follow Marcius.  /

_source.text:
(Aufidius is here addressing the Volsces who help him--he's shamed by their
support, since Marcius drives them singlehandedly).
_source.quote: Officious, and not valiant, you have shamed me  /      In your condemned seconds.

_source.text:
Romans entering from both sides of the stage would signify that they had total
command of the battlefield.
_source.quote: Enter, from one side, COMINIUS with the Romans; from the other side, MARCIUS,

_source.text: the title
_source.quote: addition

_source.text: ie, my face
_source.quote: the map of my microcosm,

_source.text:
Here is a moment where the actor (or the director) has an important choice:
should the tone of "your people" imply "the people that you represent," or
"_you people_?"
_source.quote: your people  /

_source.text:
Notice how Sicinius and Brutus harangue the citizens, behaving just as
condescendingly as they accuse Coriolanus of behaving.
_source.quote: Why, had your bodies  /      No heart among you? or had you tongues to cry  /      Against the rectorship of judgment?  /

_source.text:
They dress themselves up in authority.  This speaks to Coriolanus's hatred of
all things theatrical, but also calls into question the basis of authority.
If the republican democracy that elected the tribunes as the voice of the
people is merely a show, then what, exactly, is the "noble sufferance" that
would constitute _real _authority, if such a thing exists?
_source.quote: they do prank them in authority,  /

_source.text: eyes
_source.quote: eyne,

_source.text:
Each man (usually called "the mechanicals") has a specific profession, listed
in the cast of characters, and referred to later in the scene.  Quince is a
carpenter; Snug is a joiner (a carpenter who makes cabinets or possibly
furniture); Bottom is a weaver; Flute is a bellows-mender; Snout is a tinker
(someone who would travel around mending pots and pans); and Starveling is a
tailor.
_source.quote: QUINCE, SNUG, BOTTOM, FLUTE, SNOUT, and STARVELING

_source.text:
Everything that follows here are natural phenomena attributed, in
Shakespeare's time, to discord between fairies (fog, blight, floods, disease,
unseasonable weather).  Much of the specific wording comes from Arthur
Golding's 1567 translation of Ovid's _Metamorphoses _(this was one of
Shakespeare's favorite sources).
_source.quote: Therefore the winds, piping to us in vain,   /  As in revenge, have suck'd up from the sea   /  Contagious fogs;

_source.text: watching the merchant ships on the ocean
_source.quote: Marking the embarked traders on the flood,

_source.text: molts
_source.quote: there the snake throws her enamell'd skin,

_source.text: A round dance
_source.quote: roundel

_source.text: Jerk
_source.quote: Churl,

_source.text: ripen
_source.quote: ripe

_source.text:
Bottom is calling, in other words, for an end to theatrical illusion, to which
he attributes far too much power.
_source.quote: Write me a prologue; and let the prologue seem to   /  say, we will do no harm with our swords, and that   /  Pyramus is not killed indeed; and, for the more   /  better assurance, tell them that I, Pyramus, am not   /  Pyramus, but Bottom the weaver: this will put them   /  out of fear.

_source.text: Approx. "what's up?" or "how are you?"
_source.quote: what cheer?

_source.text: In preparation of a play?
_source.quote: What, a play toward!

_source.text:
For the natural world, the Boatswain reminds Gonzalo, is indifferent to the
socially constructed hierarchy that Gonzalo presses him to remember. 'King' is
just a name. It has no independent power. The hollow and impotent reality of
the 'name of king' lurks behind many of Shakespeare's plays and haunts many of
his royal characters, such as King Richard II and King Lear.
_source.quote: What cares these roarers   /  for the name of king?

_source.text: Big-mouthed.
_source.quote: wide-chapp'd

_source.text:
In Shakespeare's own production of the play in 1611, the role of Prospero was
played by 44-year-old Richard Burbage, but from the eighteenth century until
the mid-twentieth, Prospero was nearly always performed as a grey and wizened
grandfather and played by a much older man. In the late twentieth century, the
role began to be given to actors in their fourties who played Prospero as
middle-aged.

How does Prospero's age affect the tone of the play? How does it affect his
relationship with Miranda? Some critics have argued that the middle-aged
Prospero harbors incestuous feelings for Miranda (feelings that were absent in
the sexless old man of eighteenth century productions) and that this emotional
current provides crucial motivation for his actions later in the play.
_source.quote: PROSPERO

_source.text:
Referring to Sycorax's posture. Sycorax must have been hunchbacked in old age
and bent over until her body was more curved (like a hoop) than straight.
_source.quote: grown into a hoop?

_source.text:
The other two are her father and Caliban. Interesting that Caliban is counted
as a human being here and is omitted from Miranda's count later on (see link
below). It's another example of the uneasy status of Caliban's identity.
_source.quote: This   /  Is the third man that e'er I saw,

_source.text:
Hermia had dark hair and eyes, to Helena's blond fairness.  On Lysander's
usage here, and the perception of "blackamoors" in Renaissance England more
generally, see my notes on Othello.
_source.quote: you Ethiope!

_source.text:
We get some clues as to the staging of this in Helena's speech: she's much
less furious than Hermia, but makes sure to get her insults in ("...because
she is something lower than myself").  Lysander and Demetrius must both be
restraining Hermia (or else trying, comically, to both restrain Hermia and
fawn on Helena).
_source.quote: Let her not strike me.

_source.quote: jangling

_source.quote: Abate thy hour!

Meaning Adrian, who is younger than Gonzalo, the "old cock". A cockerel is a
young rooster.

_source.text:
Gonzalo pays Antonio and Sebastian a sarcastic compliment. They are, he says,
so brave they could pull the moon out of orbit if the moon remained still for
five weeks (which would, of course, never happen).
_source.quote: You are gentlemen of brave metal; you would lift  /  the moon out of her sphere, if she would continue  /  in it five weeks without changing.  /

This is a typo - there shouldn't be a question mark here. The sentence
continuous onto the next line.

_source.quote: bottle

_source.text:
Caliban's unabashed worship of Stephano (and Stephano's wine) quickly inflates
Stephano's ego and soon Stephano will be strutting about, proclaiming himself
King of the island.

In the last scene, we saw Antonio convince Sebastian that Sebastian was the
rightful King of Naples.

How is Caliban's effect on Stephano like or unlike Antonio's upon Sebastian?
What does Caliban stand to gain from Stephano's empowerment?
_source.quote: I'll swear upon that bottle to be thy true subject;  /  for the liquor is not earthly.  /

_source.text: Feste has made up this philosopher.
_source.quote: Quinapalus?

_source.text: Orsino has prepared a speech for Cesario to deliver.
_source.quote: Most radiant, exquisite, and unmatchable beauty,-- I pray you,  /  tell me if this be the lady of the house, for I never saw her: I  /  would be loth to cast away my speech; for, besides that it is  /  excellently well penn'd, I have taken great pains to con it.

_source.text:
This is precisely the argument of Sonnet 1:

\r\n\r\n

From fairest creatures we\r\ndesire increase,

\r\nThat thereby beauty's rose might never die,

\r\nBut as the riper should by time decease,

\r\nHis tender heir might bear his memory:

\r\nBut thou, contracted to thine own bright eyes,

\r\nFeed'st thy light'st flame with self-substantial fuel,

\r\nMaking a famine where abundance lies,

\r\nThyself thy foe, to thy sweet self too cruel.

\r\nThou that art now the world's fresh ornament

\r\nAnd only herald to the gaudy spring,

\r\nWithin thine own bud buriest thy content

\r\nAnd, tender churl, makest waste in niggarding.

\r\nPity the world, or else this glutton be,

\r\nTo eat the world's due, by the grave and thee.

\r\n\r\nMen and women who are physically beautiful have the obligation to
reproduce, so that their beauty can be preserved after their death.
_source.quote: VIOLA.  /  'T is beauty truly blent whose red and white  /  Nature's own sweet and cunning hand laid on.  /  Lady, you are the cruell'st she alive,  /  If you will lead these graces to the grave,  /  And leave the world no copy.  /

_source.text:
A fantastic Shakespearean word, though not a coinage.  Shakespeare uses fadge
in two senses.  The first, "to turn out, end up," is how it's intended in this
line.  The second sense is "to succeed, turn out well," as in Love's Labour's
Lost when the Spanish buffoon Armado declares, "We will have, if this fadge
not, an antic" ("Shakespeare's Words," Crystal and Crystal).
_source.quote: fadge?

_source.text:
This beautiful song was probably written by Shaksepeare, and it's a beautiful
mix of melancholy longing ("where are you roaming?") and sensual desire ("come
kiss me, sweet and twenty.")

  
Yet, as with so much of Twelfth Night, Festes' song is both a pean to youth
and love and an elegy to them.  It recognizes that love is a passing pleasure
while refusing to cheapen or darken the vision of young love as it is
presented.  In fact, it's the passage of time that makes love so important,
and so pleasurable. "In delay there lies no plenty," sings Feste; let's get
all we can right now, because (and despite that) tomorrow isn't certain.
_source.quote: O mistress mine, where are you roaming?  /  O, stay and hear; your true love's coming,  /  That can sing both high and low:  /  Trip no further, pretty sweeting;  /  Journeys end in lovers meeting,  /  Every wise man's son doth know.  /    /  SIR ANDREW.  /  Excellent good, i' faith.  /    /  SIR TOBY.  /  Good, good.  /    /  CLOWN.  /  [Sings.]  /  What is love? 'T is not hereafter;  /  Present mirth hath present laughter;  /  What's to come is still unsure.  /  In delay there lies no plenty,  /  Then come kiss me, sweet and twenty,  /  Youth's a stuff will not endure.  /

_source.text: Ophelia prays, following Hamlet's speculation on them upon greeting her.
_source.quote: O, help him, you sweet heavens!

_source.text:
You may be wondering what bear-baiting is, and why Malvolio disapproves of it.
The Arden editors note dryly that bear-baiting is something "of which Puritans
disapproved," leaving us to ask, What is it?  Is it giving a bear a fishing
rod and letting him catch trout?  Is it luring him to you with a jar of honey?

  
It is not.  Bear-baiting is an old "sport" in which a bear is chained to a
stake and torn apart by dogs.  If you want to see it (and you may not want
to), you can by [clicking here](http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0eZi6XP5cpI).

  
It's worth noting that Thomas Macaulay's "History of England" includes this
line about bear-baiting: The Puritan hated bearbaiting, not because it gave
pain to the bear, but because it gave pleasure to the spectators.  This fits
in with what we know about Malvolio.
_source.quote: bear-baiting

_source.text:
Of course Malvolio wouldn't read the letter aloud in real life, so
Shakespeare, through Sir Toby, slyly requests us to suspend disbelief and
enjoy the comedy of the scene.
_source.quote: O, peace! and the spirit of humours intimate reading aloud to  /  him!  /

_source.text:
To whom is Hamlet's liberty a threat? Claudius tries to extend it to everyone
-- "to you yourself, to us, to every one" -- but this is a clear instance in
which our predisposition to doubting Claudius's candor is operative. He knows
by this point that Hamlet has a bone to pick, and he's looking after his own
interests. Yet Claudius is more honest than he appears; that is, Hamlet is a
threat to Gertrude (the bedroom interview, anyone?) and to the state (can you
imagine Hamlet at the helm of Denmark?). Shakespeare is a pretty good
playwright, and here he provides ample evidence of that by having the text
speak to us on three levels: a basic level (Claudius speaks and we listen); a
psychological level (Claudius is clearly a lying, good-for-nothing throne-
stealer and his motives are transparent); and a meta-level that transcends
character (Claudius may be deceiving Gertrude and himself, but he's also
saying something intelligible and instructive that the reader is made to
consider).
_source.quote: liberty is full of threats to all;

_source.text:

no one believes what anyone says anymore (Arden).

_source.text:
Allusion to a 1599 map of the "augmented Indies" (Australia etc.) which
included lots of information for sailors.

  
Rhumb lines are navigational paths which cross all meridians at the same
angle:

  
![](http://www.gracegalleries.com/images/AF/AF108.jpg)
_source.quote: he does smile  /  his face into more lines than is in the new map, with the  /  augmentation of the Indies:

_source.text:
Midsummer madness is very inappropriate indeed to Twelfth Night, which is a
January holiday.  Malvolio's mood is summery while Olivia's is wintry.

  
The critic James Simpson correlates each season with a literary mode, calling
the conflation "seasons of the soul."  It's not a rigid system, but we might
say that spring is the season for comedy and autumn is elegy, leaving winter
for tragedy and summer for satire or parody.  It's clear that Malvolio is an
autumnal character who has turned vernal.
_source.quote: midsummer madness.  /

_source.text:
Used in the older senses of spirit or essential character, as in OED 3.a:
Characteristic disposition; inclination; bent, turn or temper of mind
_source.quote: genius

_source.text:
Sir Toby is a kind of playwright in this play, writing other people's parts
and then performing them as an actor.  Here, he lets Andrew believe that his
letter is being delivered, when really his is changing the course of the plot
by giving a report of Andrew's valour to Olivia's suitor.
_source.quote: Now will not I deliver his letter; for the behaviour of the young  /  gentleman gives him out to be of good capacity and breeding; his  /  employment between his lord and my niece confirms no less:  /  therefore this letter, being so excellently ignorant, will breed  /  no terror in the youth; he will find it comes from a clodpole.  /  But, sir, I will deliver his challenge by word of mouth; set upon  /  Aguecheek a notable report of valour; and drive the gentleman, as  /  I know his youth will aptly receive it, into a most hideous  /  opinion of his rage, skill, fury, and impetuosity. This will so  /  fright them both, that they will kill one another by the look,  /  like cockatrices.  /

_source.text:
Likely from Chaucer's "Tale of Sir Thopas":

  
Listen, lordings, in good intent,

And I will tell you verrament

Of mirth and of solas,

All of a knight was fair and gent,

In battle and in tournament,

His name was Sir Thopas...

_source.text:
It's true that Lear has been "transformed" lately, but we must remember that
Goneril explained to Oswald at the beginning of this scene that she would
instruct her household staff to provoke Lear to force him to confrontation
(1.3.25, e.g.).  Goneril is similar to Edmund in these lines - clever and
conniving behind a sympathetic, solicitous front.
_source.quote: These dispositions, that of late transform you  /      From what you rightly are.  /

lines elsewhere, as in the selection from Richard II cited in the preceding
annotation.

From OED:

 **1.** A bird of prey of the family FalconidÃ¦ and subfamily MilvinÃ¦, having
long wings, tail usually forked, and no tooth in the bill.

  
This is an evocative bird for Shakespeare, and it appears elsewhere, as in
this line from Coriolanus:

  
Third Servingman

  
    Where dwellest thou?

  
CORIOLANUS

  
    Under the canopy.

  
Third Servingman

  
    Under the canopy!

  
CORIOLANUS

  
    Ay.

  
Third Servingman

  
    Where's that?

  
CORIOLANUS

  
   ** I' the city of kites and crows.**

_source.text:
"If you think this is funny, you probably aren't smart enough even to preserve
your own virginity." (And if you think _that's_ funny, you are probably living
in Jacobean England.)  Departure/shorter was a rhyme at the time (AS).
_source.quote: She that's a maid now, and laughs at my departure,  /      Shall not be a maid long, unless things be cut shorter.  /

_source.text:
In other words, "If I appear to be wounded I will have a much stronger case to
present to my father."
_source.quote: Some blood drawn on me would beget opinion.  /

_source.text:
It doesn't take much to see that Gloucester is making a Lear-esque error here.
In fact, he is doing _exactly as Lear did in scene 1.1: damning the loyal
child and trusting the betraying one_.

  
The Gloucester parallel plot doesn't appear in most of Shakespeare's sources
(the histories, _Leir, _Spenser), but Philip Sidney included it in a play from
1590.
_source.quote: Let him fly far:  /      Not in this land shall he remain uncaught;  /      And found--dispatch. The noble duke my master,  /      My worthy arch and patron, comes to-night:  /      By his authority I will proclaim it,  /      That he which finds him shall deserve our thanks,  /      Bringing the murderous coward to the stake;  /      He that conceals him, death.  /

_source.text:
This is the overarching theme of much of Kent's dialogue - the discernment of
a flatterer from an honest man.

  
This is a microcosmic version of a problem that haunts the whole play, that of
discernment of madness/sanity and spirits/reality.  I won't rehash
Greenblatt's entire argument in "Shakespeare and the Exorcists," we can say at
least that Kent's obsession with flattery is a smaller version of these larger
concerns.  If Lear, as Greenblatt suggests, is a play in which ancient
meaningful rituals have been "emptied out" (inheritance, e.g.), then flattery
is language that has similarly been emptied.  Kent's position as character is
perhaps closer to Edmund's in his naturalism than to Gloucester's in his
superstition, but Kent is that rare naturalist who will side with the
superstitious when he sees that they are in trouble.
_source.quote: To go out of my dialect, which you  /      discommend so much. I know, sir, I am no  /      flatterer: he that beguiled you in a plain  /      accent was a plain knave; which for my part  /      I will not be, though I should win your displeasure  /      to entreat me to 't.  /

_source.text:
In other words, when we are in despair the smallest goodnesses seem like
miracles (AS).
_source.quote: Nothing almost sees miracles  /      But misery:

_source.text:
Lear misconstrues the situation.  It's not that Kent hasn't been recognized as
a servant of Lear's; it's that such recognition has been useless to him as a
means of defense against Cornwall.
_source.quote: What's he that hath so much thy place mistook  /      To set thee here?  /

_source.text:
While referring to both heaven and hell, Shakespeare may be talking about
revenge or as later Hamlet discusses, he may be doubting the ghost.

  
When talking about how he must carry about his actions, Hamlet seems to be
slightly disgusted with himself and hence the usage of a "whore." Also here
Shakespeare may be hinting at a grander design.
_source.quote: Prompted to my revenge by heaven and hell,   /  Must, like a whore, unpack my heart with words,

_source.text: Tricks.
_source.quote: fetches;  /

_source.text:
Regan is, of course, colluding with Goneril.  Lear doesn't know this yet, and
assumes that if he goes to Goneril and explains the abuses he's suffered at
the hands of her sister (Kent in the stocks, etc.), she will be sympathetic to
him.  Regan knows this isn't the case.  But she presents the argument to her
father that anyone with reason can see through his mad anger ("passion") and
won't be taken in.
_source.quote: Give ear, sir, to my sister;  /      For those that mingle reason with your passion  /      Must be content to think you old, and so--  /      But she knows what she does.  /

_source.text:
Perhaps the worst cover of any song, ever, accompanied by one of the worst
videos:

  
[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=glm7cVBZjqw&feature=related](http://www.youtub
e.com/watch?v=glm7cVBZjqw&feature=related)
_source.quote: wild night:  /

_source.text:
This is the great illusion of the monarch, that the world listens to his
desires.  Keep in mind that a responsive natural world implies a natural world
with meaning, and that an unresponsive one tends precariously towards the
meaninglessness of human life.  The stakes are therefore unbearably high for
Lear in this scene.
_source.quote: Bids the winds blow the earth into the sea,  /      Or swell the curled water 'bove the main,  /

_source.text:
This is an absolutely fascinating bit of information.  A half-hour ago, Edgar
did, finally, reveal himself to his father.  But Gloucester is so overcome
with joy (at seeing Edgar) and grief (at what he's done to Edgar) that his
"flaw'd heart" simply ceases to beat.  What are we to make of this?

  
In the first place, we have already seen that Gloucester's story is in many
ways a parallel to Lear's, beginning in the very largest sense; it is a story
about a man who throws his allegiance to the wrong (evil) child, leaving the
right (good) child spurned and releasing an unstoppable chain of events
leading to his own death.  Gloucester, as we know, wasn't in most of
Shakespeare's sources.  He is absent from "The True Chronicle History of King
Leir" as well as from Monmouth's "Historia Regum Brittaniae" (c. 1135).
Shakespeare took considerable historical license by adding him in the first
place, and he uses him to great effect.

  
Gloucester - Lear's shadow - dies only a few moments before Lear, and he dies
just at the moment when his lost child is restored to him.  This is exactly
what will happen to Lear in the play's final seconds, and so Gloucester's
death presages and prefigures Lear's own death.

  
We also have to ask ourselves whether Edgar's decision to delay open
recognition of Gloucester as his father was the right one, given what
happened.  Cavell notes that Gloucester compared the joy of "touching" Edgar
to the joy of having his sight restored; the one would be as good as the
other.  By denying Gloucester the joy of recognizing him, then, Edgar is
denying Gloucester his sight.  He is doing precisely the thing that the play's
most evil characters (like Regan and Cornwall) have done in the blinding
scene.  Good and evil have ceased to be distinct categories.
_source.quote: By nursing them, my lord. List a brief tale;  /      And when 'tis told, O, that my heart would burst!  /      The bloody proclamation to escape,  /      That follow'd me so near,--O, our lives' sweetness!  /      That we the pain of death would hourly die  /      Rather than die at once!--taught me to shift  /      Into a madman's rags; to assume a semblance  /      That very dogs disdain'd: and in this habit  /      Met I my father with his bleeding rings,  /      Their precious stones new lost: became his guide,  /      Led him, begg'd for him, saved him from despair;  /      Never,--O fault!--reveal'd myself unto him,  /      Until some half-hour past, when I was arm'd:  /      Not sure, though hoping, of this good success,  /      I ask'd his blessing, and from first to last  /      Told him my pilgrimage: but his flaw'd heart,  /      Alack, too weak the conflict to support!  /      'Twixt two extremes of passion, joy and grief,  /      Burst smilingly.  /

_source.text:
Again: good and evil are shifting across a porous barier here.  The writ on
Lear's life is a significant way in which Shakespeare altered his sources.
Most stories of Old King Leir ended, of course, with Lear's restoration to the
throne and the promise that Cordelia would succeed him.  With Edmund's writ,
Shakespeare does away completely with the possibility of normal succession.
_source.quote: I pant for life: some good I mean to do,  /      Despite of mine own nature. Quickly send,  /      Be brief in it, to the castle; for my writ  /      Is on the life of Lear and on Cordelia:  /      Nay, send in time.  /

favorites...for his villains. Compare Edmund's "Thou, Nature, art my goddess"

the same in thine own act and valour as thou art in desire?"

married."  It's not unusual for Shakespeare's plays to have inconsistencies

_source.text:
Remember the "musty superfluity" of Act I Scene 1 (ie, the people): now
Coriolanus refuses to distinguish between that "musty chaff" and the "poor
grain or two" that are his friends and supporters.

As [Marjorie Garber](http://www.amazon.com/Shakespeare-After-All-Marjorie-
Garber/dp/0385722141/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&s=books&qid=1220280398&sr=8-1) notes,
this makes Coriolanus a kind of grim reaper--just as the reaper's scythe
levels all the grain in a field, so does Death level all the living, without
distinguishing between good and evil.
_source.quote: He could not stay to pick them in a pile  /      Of noisome musty chaff: he said 'twas folly,  /      For one poor grain or two, to leave unburnt,  /      And still to nose the offence.  /

_source.text:
The first we learn of Olivia's dead father. In the Barnabe Rich version, the
duke (there named Apolonius), is suitor to a woman named Juliana (whom
Shakespeare turned into Olivia).  But unlike Olivia, Juliana is a widow - this
led to some confusion among those familiar with Rich's story; they sometimes
mistakenly believed Olivia to be a widow.
_source.quote: A virtuous maid, the daughter of a count  /  That died some twelvemonth since, then leaving her  /  In the protection of his son, her brother,  /  Who shortly also died; for whose dear love,  /  They say, she hath abjur'd the company  /  And sight of men.  /

_source.text:
Viola's first instinct is to serve Olivia, not to meet Duke Orsino.  By scene
1.4, though, she has already been in the service of the Duke for three days.
Did Shakespeare lose track of his own set up?  Is Viola's change of plans
merely a symptom of the chaos of Illyria, especially for one who's been
shipwrecked on its shores?
_source.quote: O that I serv'd that lady,  /  And might not be delivered to the world,  /  Till I had made mine own occasion mellow,  /  What my estate is!  /

_source.text:
"Many sorts of music" makes us think of Orsino's opening lines: "If music be
the food of love..."  Viola is already connected with Orsino's concept of
love, though she doesn't know it yet.
_source.quote: And speak to him in many sorts of music  /

_source.text:
A spinning top.  Sir Toby's describing a state of drunkenness so advanced that
the room seems to spin.

_source.text:
The life-as-a-candle idea is one of Shakespeare's favorites--Macbeth's eulogy
of Lady Macbeth ("Out, out brief candle") is probably the most famous. Here,
though, Othello compares the light of Desdemona's life to the light of the
candle only to dissect the comparison: nothing is more _un_like, because a
candle can be re-lit.
_source.quote: Put out the light, and then put out the light:

_source.quote: Cesario,

Officers talk about in Act II Scene 2, and from the tribunes themselves.
_source.quote: His heart's his mouth:  /

_source.text:
That is, if Coriolanus's friends were to plead with him to spare Rome, they
would then be behaving as the tribunes and plebeians would behave.
_source.quote: for his best friends, if they  /      Should say 'Be good to Rome,' they charged him even  /      As those should do that had deserved his hate,  /      And therein show'd like enemies.  /

_source.text:
One of the major motifs of this play is naming: Caius Marcius quickly gains
the cognomen "Coriolanus" for defeating Corioles (one of the only two gifts,
along with a horse, that he accepts from Cominius).  When he first comes to
Aufidius, he unveils himself in the hopes that naming will not be necessary,
but remains unrecognizable.  Leaving Rome, his mother, his wife, and his
children, he obliterates his proper names, and retains only the cognomen
achieved in battle, Coriolanus ("Only that name remains").

Now Coriolanus is a man without a name, without an identity, rejecting even
the name "Coriolanus"--he can't in all good conscience, after all, take the
side of the Volscians while using the name he gained from burning their city.
He will take a new name, he says to Cominius, when he conquers Rome--but what
kind of name could be given to the Roman conqueror of Rome?
_source.quote: Coriolanus  /      He would not answer to: forbad all names;  /      He was a kind of nothing, titleless,  /      Till he had forged himself a name o' the fire  /      Of burning Rome.  /

_source.text:
"leasing" here means falsehood--"stamped the leasing" thus means
"authenticated falsehood."  Menenius is arguing (somewhat oddly) that he's
such a good friend to Coriolanus that he has boasted so strongly of his deeds
that he has almost lied about them.
_source.quote: Have almost stamp'd the leasing:

_source.text: active as a faction or partisan
_source.quote: factionary

_source.text:
Menenius bases his rhetoric here on emotional ties of kinship and love, which
are unlikely (as he doesn't yet understand) to succeed with Coriolanus, who
has abdicated what shred of these he once had upon his exile from Rome.

The play is examining here the question of military identity.  The traditional
Roman view, as expressed by Volumnia, is that a soldier must place his larger
purpose (ie, service of the state) ahead of any personal commitments.  Yet it
is precisely these commitments that Cominius and Menenius are exploiting to
try to get Coriolanus to return to Rome.
_source.quote: thy old father Menenius does! O my son, my son!  /

_source.text: Menenius is crying.
_source.quote: here's  /      water to quench it.

_source.text:
This, after all, is the Roman military fantasy: that the strongest bonds
(indeed, the only bonds that should count) are those forged on the battlefield
between soldiers, those that stem from shared honor, bravery, and strength.
If this were the case, then man would be, as Coriolanus longs to be, "author
of himself" and bound to nothing outside his own choosing.  The bonds of
nature--of filial duty, marital love, and parental responsibility--not only
distract from the duties of the soldier to his state, but _soften _that
soldier and make him less than what he ought to be.

Yet even as the play constructs this fantasy, it shows us its holes and frayed
edges.  Even Coriolanus "melts" to see his family, and the pain of Menenius as
he's being mocked by Aufidius's watchmen makes us think that Coriolanus does
indeed owe him some loyalty, not as a Roman, but as a friend.
_source.quote: As if a man were author of himself  /      And knew no other kin.  /

_source.text: workmen, working class
_source.quote: mechanics:

_source.text:
Volumnia's parallel here is between Rome as "womb" of its citizens and her own
maternal body.  This is a mutation of the body politic--rather than the
individual body as a metaphor for the state, the state is a metaphorical
extension of the womb.  There is nothing political about this: the state, in
this conception, is entirely personal.
_source.quote: thou shalt no sooner  /      March to assault thy country than to tread--  /      Trust to't, thou shalt not--on thy mother's womb,  /      That brought thee to this world.  /

_source.text: Battery here means a military assault, probably one with giant noisy guns.
_source.quote: battery.

_source.text: a lingering death
_source.quote: death by inches.  /

_source.text:
Though this repetition may seem awkward, it achieves its intended effect. By
emphasizing the blood tie between himself and Antonio, Prospero evokes all the
duties and loyalties associated with a family and thus makes Antonio's
betrayals seem all the more despicable for being acted out against his own
brother.
_source.quote: Flesh and blood,  /  You, brother mine,

_source.text:
The fight for Edmund's love has escaped into the open, where even Albany is
not spared from it.
_source.quote: REGAN  /    /      In my rights,  /      By me invested, he compeers the best.  /    /  GONERIL  /    /      That were the most, if he should husband you.  /    /  REGAN  /    /      Jesters do oft prove prophets.  /    /  GONERIL  /    /      Holla, holla!  /      That eye that told you so look'd but a-squint.  /

_source.text:
Albany is given this line only in Q1 and Q2.  In F, the line (5.3.250) is
Edgar's.
_source.quote: ALBANY  /    /      Haste thee, for thy life.  /

_source.text:
If Cordelia lives, then Lear will be able to find meaning in his suffering.
Greenblatt notes that Lear, like the audience, wants to have a _reason _for
everything that's happened in the play.  In the 1681 version, it was easy to
make meaning out of act five: there had been tremendous suffering up unti that
point but now that suffering has given way (inevitably led to) greater order
and perhaps even love.

  
Spenser's version ends with Lear being restored to the throne.  "She" is
Cordelia:

  
So to his crowne she him restor'd againe,

  In which he dyde, made ripe for death by eld.

  
But Shakespeare denies us that ending.
_source.quote: if it be so,  /      It is a chance which does redeem all sorrows  /      That ever I have felt.  /

_source.text:
This is another false promise of Shakespeare's.  In the King Leir story the
king does indeed take back the throne, but here we know Lear's death to be
imminent and so Albany's promise will not be fulfilled.
_source.quote: What comfort to this great decay may come  /      Shall be applied: for us we will resign,  /      During the life of this old majesty,  /      To him our absolute power:  /

_source.text:
We have come back to this image of "unaccommodated man."  Lear wanted to
unbutton his clothes during the storm scene, shouting to the Fool:

  
Off, off, you lendings!

come unbutton here.

  
Some editors suggest that Lear is unbuttoning his own clothes, while some say
that the line refers to Cordelia.  Shakespeare is playing a carefully
calculated game with this line, because he has established the connection
between clothing and artifice throughout the play.  We can reasonably expect
that Lear will come to recognize Cordelia's death, and accept his own part in
it, when he begins the symbolic gesture of loosening his clothes.  But this is
not what happens.
_source.quote: Pray you, undo this button:

_source.text:
In the first printed version of Hamlet, the first Quarto of 1603, this line,
one of the most famous in world literature, reads: To be or not to be, that is
the point.
_source.quote: To be, or not to be: that is the question:

_source.text:
Roderigo is described in the _dramatis personae _(the list of roles) as a
"gulled (or fooled) gentleman [of Venice]." Though Roderigo is clearly
Othello's inferior, Shakespeare is setting up the two "gulled" men as foils
for one another. The two men are both in love with Desdemona, and both succumb
to their jealousy. These parallels help the contours of Othello's personality
come into relief: what is it _exactly _that makes Othello noble and Roderigo
just silly?
_source.quote: RODERIGO

_source.text:
"By God's wounds"--Zounds is the Elizabethan equivalent of darn, drat, shoot,
or frick.
_source.quote: 'Zounds,

_source.text:
The class difference here is important: if Brabantio called someone of his own
rank a villain, it could lead to a duel. Iago is his inferior, so he has to
swallow his words.
_source.quote: Thou art a villain.   /  IAGO You are--a senator.

_source.text:
The Duke's shift to prose, especially after two speeches of rhyming couplets,
is notable. Imagine what this would sound like on stage: I think it really
separates the private matters of Desdemona and Othello from the public
business under discussion. Othello switches right back into verse in his next
speech: what effect would this have on the stage?
_source.quote: The Turk with a most mighty preparation makes for   /  Cyprus. Othello, the fortitude of the place is best   /  known to you; and though we have there a substitute   /  of most allowed sufficiency, yet opinion, a   /  sovereign mistress of effects, throws a more safer   /  voice on you: you must therefore be content to   /  slubber the gloss of your new fortunes with this   /  more stubborn and boisterous expedition.

_source.text: The previous governor of Cyprus, replaced by Othello.
_source.quote: MONTANO

_source.text:
The cleaner version: "She's beautiful enough for the gods." The dirtier
version: "She's a tramp, like Jove was a womanizer."

_source.text:
Goneril's complaint that Lear's rabble is causing chaos in her household is
received by Lear as a breaking of the bond between father and daughter.  "Yet
have I left a daughter" refers to Regan, to whose castle he'll go next, and
implies the loss of Cordelia and Goneril - those two are now subsumed, in
Lear's mind, in the same "bastard" category to which Edmund belongs.
_source.quote: Darkness and devils!  /      Saddle my horses; call my train together:  /      Degenerate bastard! I'll not trouble thee.  /      Yet have I left a daughter.  /    /  GONERIL  /    /      You strike my people; and your disorder'd rabble  /      Make servants of their betters.  /

_source.text:
Again, I recommend checking out Laurence Olivier's Lear as you read these
lines.  You'll see that this is staged with lots of people in the background
eating, drinking, saddling horses.  Lear's speeches are both completely public
and unintelligibly private - especially the "Lear, Lear, Lear!" line, which
may be read as a moment of realization that things have taken a wrong turn,
and yet contain with in them the tag "Go, go, my people," which hints at the
inexorability of the forces that Lear has released, and continues to release.

tch?v=hQzDIYdFIy0&feature=related)
_source.quote: thou liest.  /      My train are men of choice and rarest parts,  /      That all particulars of duty know,  /      And in the most exact regard support  /      The worships of their name. O most small fault,  /      How ugly didst thou in Cordelia show!  /      That, like an engine, wrench'd my frame of nature  /      From the fix'd place; drew from heart all love,  /      And added to the gall. O Lear, Lear, Lear!  /      Beat at this gate, that let thy folly in,  /

_source.text:
"Your feet will be so calloused (as your wit is), that you won't need shoes
after undertaking this journey to Regan."
_source.quote: Fool  /    /      If a man's brains were in's heels, were't not in  /      danger of kibes?  /    /  KING LEAR  /    /      Ay, boy.  /    /  Fool  /    /      Then, I prithee, be merry; thy wit shall ne'er go  /      slip-shod.  /    /  KING LEAR  /    /      Ha, ha, ha!  /

_source.text:
This is a very elegant image.  It's night and the ground is covered in
moonlight, so Kent proposes to use Oswald's wounded or fallen body to soak it
up.
_source.quote: Draw, you  /      rogue: for, though it be night, yet the moon  /      shines; I'll make a sop o' the moonshine of you:  /

_source.text:
Kent sees that Cornwall thinks poorly of his way of speaking (that is, his
affected way of speaking - Kent is a noble of Gloucester's status), and so he
plays a game with him by ratcheting up his tone to a higher, more literary
one.
_source.quote: Sir, in good sooth, in sincere verity,  /      Under the allowance of your great aspect,  /      Whose influence, like the wreath of radiant fire  /      On flickering Phoebus' front,--  /

_source.text:
Greenblatt notes that in Lear, the evil characters are always very certain of
their actions (and - in a larger implication to which we'll turn our attention
later on - of who they are as people).
_source.quote: I'll answer that.  /    /  REGAN  /    /      My sister may receive it much more worse,  /      To have her gentleman abused, assaulted,  /      For following her affairs. Put in his legs.  /

_source.text:
Kent is down.  But he belives in some kind of supernatural order of the
universe (in this case, Boethius's wheel of fortune), just as Lear and
Gloucester do, to some extent.
_source.quote: Fortune, good night: smile once more: turn thy wheel!  /

_source.text:
This is another thing that appears in Harsnett's book as a symptom of a fake
exorcism.
_source.quote: Hysterica passio,

_source.text:
As defined in Edward Jordan's "Brief discourse of a disease called the
suffocation of the mother" (1605), the mother (probably short for smother) was
an "affect of the womb" that led to choking and other discomforts.  It's not
really important exactly what the medical definition of the thing is.  It _is
_important that Lear connects emotional weakness - like the "climbing sorrow"
- as essentially feminine, and fears its intrusion into his mind and body
("thy element's below" - stay back!).
_source.quote: mother

_source.text:
Lear is in the winter of his life and the winter of his powers.  Like the
ant's instinct to gather food during the summer and rest during the winter,
the process of human aging is natural and unstoppable.  There are certain
things that simply _happen_.
_source.quote: We'll set thee to school to an ant, to teach thee  /      there's no labouring i' the winter.

_source.text:
One of the most terrible things about Lear's position here is that he is
dependent on the very people who are abusing him.  Even as he appeals to Regan
for help he is revolted by his need to make such an appeal.  This type of
situation lends itself nicely to Freudian readings such as Cavell's, which
would go something like this: "Men do not just naturally not love, they learn
not to.  And our lives begin by having to accept under the name of love
whatever closeness is offered, and then by having to forgo its object"
(Adelman 86).

  
"Its object" is, of course, the infant's mother.  Contributing to Lear's
confusion of female categories (mother/daughter/lover) is his return, in old
age and madness, to a kind of infantalized state of rejection of women and
dependency on them.
_source.quote: O Regan, she hath tied  /      Sharp-tooth'd unkindness, like a vulture, here:  /    /      Points to his heart  /      I can scarce speak to thee; thou'lt not believe  /      With how depraved a quality--O Regan!  /

_source.text:
"If need were the only thing that guided man were need, then you, my daughter,
wouldn't be wearing that skimpy outfit, because you would be wearing something
ugly but much more practical."

  
The dress that Regan is wearing, like Lear's train of knights, are the outward
shows that men gather to themselves.  The notion that man's life is "cheap as
a beast's" without all of the material things with which we surround ourselves
echoes a little of Hobbes, and indeed Greenblatt sees Shakespeare as
responding to Hobbes's philosophy obliquely in this play.  Where Hobbes would
no doubt agree that the natural state of man matches Lear's description, he
would suggest that such a state is the starting point and we are moving away
from it as civilization advances.  Shakespeare would say that we are moving
_toward_ it.
_source.quote: If only to go warm were gorgeous,  /      Why, nature needs not what thou gorgeous wear'st,  /      Which scarcely keeps thee warm.

_source.text:
Kent and the gentleman will split up to go find the king.  "In which your pain
that way" means "in pursuit of which goal you go that way."  They plan to
shout for one another when they've found him.
_source.quote: Few words, but, to effect, more than all yet;  /      That, when we have found the king,--in which your pain  /      That way, I'll this,--he that first lights on him  /      Holla the other.  /

_source.text:
If Demetrius even bothers to thank Helena for the information, he'll do so
only grudgingly.  I think this line (and the idea of enriching her pain) says
a lot about Helena, and how much she is willing to give to get almost nothing
in return.  There's more than a shred of self-pity here, which is important, I
think, lest we feel _too _sorry for Helena.
_source.quote: If I have thanks, it is a dear expense:

_source.text: Being bald from the "French disease," syphilis.
_source.quote: Some of your French crowns have no hair at all, and   /  then you will play bare-faced.

_source.text:
'Prospero' means 'fortunate' and 'prosperous.' Keep this in mind as you read
through the play. Was Shakespeare being sincere or ironic in selecting
Prospero's name?

_source.text:
Stories about a man changing into an ass, or an ass suddenly given the power
of speech, were more common in sixteenth-century England than you might think.
In the city of Chester, a play about Balaam and his talking ass was one of the
most popular and long-lasting of the medieval religious plays.  The most
famous story of a man being transformed into an ass was
[Apuleius](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apuleius)'s "The Golden Ass,"
translated into English in 1566, in which a beautiful princess lavishes
adoration on the ass.  [Reginald
Scot](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reginald_Scot)'s [_The discoverie of
witchcraft_](http://books.google.com/books?id=HM9NV-hDjc0C&printsec=frontcover
&dq=discoverie+of+witchcraft&ei=NKSESJ_ePI6UiAHVyISjCA&sig=ACfU3U1Qr-HaRVkf-
NUsRdr7QCVuezi00Q#PPR3,M1) (1584) relates the story of a sailor transformed
into an ass by a witch.  Happening upon a church just as the consecration of
the mass is about to take place, he “fell down in the churchyard upon the
knees of his hinder legs and did lift his forefeet over his head as the priest
doth hold the sacrament at the elevation.”  The townspeople, amazed at the
sight of a praying ass, figured out what had happened, found the witch, and
forced her to remove the spell.

Above all, Bottom was an ass before Puck transformed his head; an ass getting
an ass's head is not only hilarious and ironic, but reinforces Shakespeare's
mockery of theatrical literalism (the audience _knows _that  the Lion is not
real before he says his name; they would understand that Snout is supposed to
be a wall whether or not he had lime and roughcast about him).
_source.quote: with an ass's head

_source.text: Tell the truth once and for all.
_source.quote: O, once tell true,

_source.text:
I'm crying as I make these vows to you, and tears are the sign of truth (or
"badge of faith").
_source.quote: Scorn and derision never come in tears:   /  Look, when I vow, I weep; and vows so born,   /  In their nativity all truth appears.   /  How can these things in me seem scorn to you,   /  Bearing the badge of faith, to prove them true?
